subject: Critical Thinking
title: Simpson's Paradox: Data That Lies When Combined
description: A 60-second lesson on Simpson's Paradox: Data That Lies When Combined.

hook.text: UC Berkeley was sued for gender bias in admissions. The overall data showed bias. But every department favored women.

buildup.text: Simpson's Paradox: a trend that appears in several groups reverses when the groups are combined.

discovery.text: Women applied to competitive departments with low admission rates. Men applied to easier ones. Aggregating hid this.

twist.text: A drug can be better for men AND better for women individually, but worse for the combined population.

climax.text: Simpson's Paradox shows that aggregated data can tell the exact opposite story from disaggregated data. Both are 'true.'

punchline.text: The data doesn't lie. But the summary might.

quiz.question: What is Simpson's Paradox?
options: A trend that appears in groups but reverses when groups are combined
A statistical error caused by small samples
